parts.text:
[Statement 1]: The most effective actions for increasing natural enemy populations on farmland include several habitat management and chemical control strategies.
[Statement 2]: Creating beetle banks provides habitat for natural enemies.
[Statement 3]: Studies found higher numbers of invertebrate predators on beetle banks compared to surrounding crops.
[Statement 4]: The effects of beetle banks on invertebrate predator numbers varied with time and location.
[Statement 5]: Natural regeneration of ground cover beneath perennial crops shows mixed results for increasing natural enemy populations.
[Statement 6]: Some studies found more natural enemies in natural ground cover.
[Statement 7]: The increase of natural enemies in natural ground cover was particularly a short-term effect for most natural enemy groups.
[Statement 8]: Planting specific vegetation can attract and support natural enemies.
[Statement 9]: Growing non-crop plants that produce chemicals attractive to natural enemies resulted in higher numbers of natural enemies in three of four studies.
[Statement 10]: One replicated, randomised, controlled trial showed that growing non-crop plants that produce attractive chemicals increased natural enemy populations.
[Statement 11]: Planting flowers in strips led to more natural enemies in fields with planted flower strips compared to fields without the flower strips.
[Statement 12]: Planting hedgerows resulted in more natural enemies in fields with hedgerows compared to fields with weedy edges in some comparisons.
[Statement 13]: Planting nettle strips in field margins resulted in higher numbers of aphid predator species.
[Statement 14]: Using chemicals to attract natural enemies increased natural enemy populations in five of thirteen studies from multiple continents.
[Statement 15]: Eight studies found that the positive effects of using chemicals to attract natural enemies varied between enemy groups, sites or study dates.
[Statement 16]: Two of four studies found that higher doses of attractive chemicals attracted more natural enemies.
[Statement 17]: Management practices that reduce pesticide impacts support natural enemy populations.
[Statement 18]: Delaying herbicide use resulted in more natural enemies in two randomised, replicated, controlled trials.
[Statement 19]: The benefits of delaying herbicide use were seen in some, but not all, natural enemy groups.
[Statement 20]: Incorporating parasitism rates when setting thresholds for insecticide use resulted in acceptable levels of crop damage while considering natural enemy activity.
[Statement 21]: The effects on natural enemy populations were not directly monitored when incorporating parasitism rates for insecticide thresholds.
[Statement 22]: Mass-emergence devices showed limited effectiveness for increasing natural enemy populations.
[Statement 23]: One study in Switzerland on mass-emergence devices found higher parasitism at one site but no effect at another site.
[Statement 24]: Adding compost to soil showed mixed results for increasing natural enemy populations.
[Statement 25]: One study found similar ratios of natural enemies to pests in plots with or without added compost.
[Statement 26]: One study found similar percentages of pests were consumed by natural enemies in plots with or without added compost.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What are the most effective actions for increasing natural enemy populations on farmland?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Several natural pest control measures can have negative economic impacts on farmer profitability in North America.
[Statement 2]: Studies on organic farming conversion found one negative effect on yield and one mixed effect.
[Statement 3]: Three studies on organic farming conversion found no or inconsistent effects on yield.
[Statement 4]: One study found that net profit from organic farming decreased unless the produce received a premium.
[Statement 5]: Another study on organic farming found a negative or no effect on profit.
[Statement 6]: Six replicated, controlled studies from the USA found lower cash crop yields in some plots with winter cover crops compared to plots without winter cover crops.
[Statement 7]: Yield reductions from winter cover crops represent direct revenue losses for farmers.
[Statement 8]: One controlled study from the USA found lower yield and lower profit in alley cropped plots.
[Statement 9]: A study from the Philippines reported that alley cropping resulted in similar or lower yields.
[Statement 10]: One study found that alley cropped plots had lower costs but also resulted in lower profit.
[Statement 11]: One study on push-pull systems found higher production costs in the first year of implementation.
[Statement 12]: The study on push-pull systems found that production costs became equal or lower in the years following the first year.
[Statement 13]: Two of three studies found that crop growth was inhibited by allelopathic plant remains.
[Statement 14]: Three randomised, replicated, controlled studies found positive, negative and mixed effects on yield when comparing plots amended with allelopathic plant remains with weeded controls.
[Statement 15]: One study found that amending soils with allelopathic plant remains increased profit compared to unweeded controls.
[Statement 16]: The study on allelopathic plant remains found amending soils did not increase profit when compared to weeded controls.
[Statement 17]: One replicated, randomized, controlled study from the USA found smaller lettuces in fields planted with flowers in five out of six configurations.
[Statement 18]: The negative economic impacts of natural pest control primarily manifest as reduced yields and higher implementation costs.
[Statement 19]: The negative economic impacts of natural pest control can also manifest as lower profits and crop growth inhibition during transition periods.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__For a farmer focused on profitability in North America, what are the potential negative economic impacts of actions designed to improve natural pest control?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Farmers in the USA have several natural weed control methods available.
[Statement 2]: Allelopathic plant incorporation involves incorporating plant remains into soil that produce weed-controlling chemicals.
[Statement 3]: Six studies on allelopathic plant incorporation found reductions in weed growth.
[Statement 4]: The effects of allelopathic plant incorporation on weed growth varied between years and weed groups.
[Statement 5]: Cover crops can be grown in arable fields.
[Statement 6]: Four studies found fewer weeds in plots with cover crops compared to plots without them.
[Statement 7]: Some studies found that the effects of cover crops on weeds were inconsistent.
[Statement 8]: Competitive planting involves growing plants that compete with damaging weeds.
[Statement 9]: All nine studies on competitive planting found reduced weed plant weight or ground cover.
[Statement 10]: One study showed that crop rotation using a canola-wheat sequence reduced weed biomass when compared to a wheat-wheat sequence.
[Statement 11]: Tillage management offers multiple approaches to weed control.
[Statement 12]: Seven studies showed that reduced tillage resulted in more weeds in most comparisons.
[Statement 13]: No-tillage had inconsistent effects, with multiple studies finding sometimes more and sometimes fewer weeds.
[Statement 14]: A general reduction in tillage increased the numbers of some weeds according to studies across European countries.
[Statement 15]: Two studies showed that mixed pasture systems had reduced weeds when compared to monoculture pasture.
[Statement 16]: Ground cover management in orchards and vineyards found fewer weeds in one comparison and more weeds in another.
[Statement 17]: The natural regeneration of ground cover beneath perennial crops provided weed suppression benefits.
[Statement 18]: Three studies found more weeds in organically farmed fields after converting to organic farming.
[Statement 19]: The effects of converting to organic farming on weed populations varied between crops and years.
[Statement 20]: Surface mulching was tested for grass control but showed limited effectiveness in one study.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What actions are available to a farmer in the USA to control weeds using natural methods?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Several alternative pest management methods are available for perennial tree crops like orchards besides using insecticides.
[Statement 2]: Ground cover management in orchards shows promise for pest management.
[Statement 3]: Planting or maintaining ground cover in orchards or vineyards can affect pest regulation.
[Statement 4]: Some studies found more leafhopper eggs were parasitized in plots with cover crops compared to plots with bare fallows.
[Statement 5]: The results of using ground cover for pest management were inconsistent across studies.
[Statement 6]: Physical exclusion methods are effective for pest management.
[Statement 7]: Excluding ants that protect pests by using glue or pesticide barriers can reduce pest numbers in crops including cherry, grape, grapefruit, orange, and pecan trees.
[Statement 8]: Excluding ants that protect pests can increase parasitism by natural enemies.
[Statement 9]: Push-pull systems, which combine trap and repellent crops, represent an alternative approach to pest management.
[Statement 10]: Combining trap and repellent crops increased parasitism of stem borer larvae in some studies.
[Statement 11]: The use of trap and repellent crops resulted in fewer pests and higher yields in some studies.
[Statement 12]: Chemical attractants for natural enemies offer potential benefits for pest management.
[Statement 13]: Using chemicals to attract natural enemies increased parasitism in some studies on crops including apple, grape, grapefruit, and orange.
[Statement 14]: The use of chemical attractants resulted in more natural enemies, though effects varied between enemy groups, sites, and study dates.
[Statement 15]: Beneficial insect conservation can be enhanced through habitat management.
[Statement 16]: Planting nettle strips resulted in higher numbers of aphid predator species.
[Statement 17]: Green lacewings, a type of aphid predator, were only found on planted nettles in some studies.
[Statement 18]: Incorporating parasitism rates when setting thresholds for pest control decisions resulted in acceptable levels of crop damage from pests in tomato studies.
[Statement 19]: Alley cropping showed mixed results on pest management.
[Statement 20]: Some studies on alley cropping found fewer pests, while others found variable effects depending on pest groups and study years.
[Statement 21]: Conversion to organic farming demonstrated higher soil organism diversity in some orchard studies.
[Statement 22]: Conversion to organic farming demonstrated higher fruit quality in some orchard studies.
[Statement 23]: The conversion to organic farming had mixed effects on orchard yields.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__Besides using insecticides, what are some alternative methods for managing pests in perennial tree crops like orchards?
_claude-sonnet-4__What is the evidence for using habitat manipulation within crop fields to boost natural enemy numbers?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Evidence shows that various habitat manipulation strategies within crop fields can effectively boost natural enemy numbers.
[Statement 2]: Beetle banks create refuge habitats that increase predator numbers.
[Statement 3]: Studies found more invertebrate predators on beetle banks than in surrounding crops.
[Statement 4]: Predators increased in adjacent crops near beetle banks.
[Statement 5]: The effects of beetle banks on predator numbers in adjacent crops varied with time.
[Statement 6]: The movement of predators from beetle banks to crops was sometimes slow.
[Statement 7]: Growing non-crop plants that produce chemicals attractive to natural enemies has shown positive results.
[Statement 8]: Studies found higher numbers of natural enemies in plots with plants that produce chemicals attractive to natural enemies.
[Statement 9]: Studies found that growing non-crop plants attractive to natural enemies decreased pest populations or damage.
[Statement 10]: Flower strips planted within agricultural systems demonstrate benefits for natural enemies.
[Statement 11]: Studies found more natural enemies in fields with planted flower strips compared to fields without planted flower strips.
[Statement 12]: Controlled studies found more natural enemies in planted flower strips than on bare ground.
[Statement 13]: Studies found greater pest reduction or higher proportions of parasitized pests in fields and farms with planted flower strips.
[Statement 14]: Hedgerows provide habitat that supports natural enemies.
[Statement 15]: One study found more natural enemies in fields with hedgerows compared to fields with weedy edges.
[Statement 16]: A study found a higher proportion of pest eggs were parasitized in tomato fields with hedgerows up to 100m into the crop.
[Statement 17]: Intercropping systems boost beneficial insects.
[Statement 18]: Studies found increased ground beetle abundance when intercropping cabbage with French beans or clover.
[Statement 19]: Field margin management contributes to natural enemy populations.
[Statement 20]: Studies showed that nettle strips in field margins resulted in higher numbers of aphid predator species.
[Statement 21]: Three insect families including green lacewings were found only on nettles.
[Statement 22]: Uncultivated margins around fields support more invertebrates including beneficial species.
[Statement 23]: Studies found that uncultivated margins support more invertebrates and higher plant diversity than conventionally managed margins.

[Statement 1]: Several interventions show benefits for reducing pest populations in maize farming.
[Statement 2]: Push-pull cropping systems show strong evidence for pest reduction.
[Statement 3]: Studies have found that push-pull cropping systems result in fewer pests.
[Statement 4]: Push-pull cropping systems combine trap and repellent crops.
[Statement 5]: Push-pull cropping systems have demonstrated increased parasitism of stem borer larvae in studies from Kenya.
[Statement 6]: Push-pull cropping systems have led to more natural predators.
[Statement 7]: Push-pull cropping systems have resulted in fewer witchweeds.
[Statement 8]: Genetically modified crops that produce pesticides can be used to replace conventional pesticide application.
[Statement 9]: A study found that genetically modified maize expressing Bacillus thuringiensis kurstaki (Btk) toxin was effective against the European corn borer.
[Statement 10]: Crop rotation systems have shown pest reduction benefits.
[Statement 11]: Studies found crop rotation reduced pest populations and crop diseases in at least one year or site.
[Statement 12]: Some studies found that fewer insecticide treatments were needed on rotated plots.
[Statement 13]: The effectiveness of crop rotation varied depending on the rotation crops used.
[Statement 14]: The crops studied for rotation effectiveness included maize among others.
[Statement 15]: Alley cropping shows mixed results for pest control.
[Statement 16]: Some replicated, controlled studies found more pests in alley cropped plots.
[Statement 17]: One study found fewer pests in alley cropped plots.
[Statement 18]: The effects of alley cropping varied with the pest group and between years.
[Statement 19]: Converting to organic farming systems shows limited evidence for pest reduction specifically in maize.
[Statement 20]: Only one of eight studies found that organic farming reduced pests or disease.
[Statement 21]: Two studies found that organic farming resulted in more pests.
[Statement 22]: Other studies on organic farming showed mixed effects on pests.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__For a maize farmer, what are the most beneficial interventions to reduce pest populations?
_claude-sonnet-4__What is the evidence base for actions that increase pest parasitism rates in perennial crops?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: There is limited but positive evidence for several interventions that can increase pest parasitism rates in perennial crops.
[Statement 2]: One replicated, controlled study from Australia found that leaving part of crops unharvested increased predation and parasitism rates of pest eggs in the unharvested strips.
[Statement 3]: In perennial crop systems, one study from the USA found that more leafhopper eggs were parasitized in plots with cover crops compared to bare fallows in orchards or vineyards.
[Statement 4]: The increased parasitism of leafhopper eggs in plots with cover crops was only observed in one of six comparisons.
[Statement 5]: Two studies from the USA found inconsistent differences or no differences in parasitism of leafhopper eggs between plots with or without ground cover.
[Statement 6]: The use of mass-emergence devices showed mixed results for increasing pest parasitism.
[Statement 7]: A study in Switzerland found that using mass-emergence devices in urban areas led to higher parasitism at one site but had no effect at another site.
[Statement 8]: Four studies from China, Germany, India and Kenya found that growing non-crop plants that produce chemicals attracting natural enemies resulted in higher numbers of natural enemies.
[Statement 9]: The higher numbers of natural enemies from growing specific non-crop plants were observed in fruit trees.
[Statement 10]: One study found no effect on parasitism when the non-crop plant used was not attractive to natural enemies in laboratory studies.
[Statement 11]: Alley cropping systems showed variable results for increasing pest parasitism.
[Statement 12]: Two of four studies found that the effects of alley cropping on parasitism varied between study sites, sampling dates, pest life stages, or crop alley width.
[Statement 13]: Two studies found that alley cropping had no effect on parasitism.
[Statement 14]: A controlled study from New Zealand found that using parasitism rates to inform spraying decisions resulted in acceptable levels of crop damage from pests.
[Statement 15]: The New Zealand study on using parasitism rates to inform spraying decisions was tested on tomato rather than perennial crops.

[Statement 1]: In North American studies, several different farming systems show varying effects on crop yields compared to conventional farming.
[Statement 2]: Organic farming systems show mixed effects on crop yields.
[Statement 3]: According to six North American studies, organic farming had one positive effect, one negative effect, one mixed effect, and three studies found no or inconsistent effects on crop yields.
[Statement 4]: One study found that with organic farming, net profit increased if produce received a premium, but otherwise profit decreased.
[Statement 5]: One replicated trial in Canada found lower yields in organically managed soils compared to conventional systems.
[Statement 6]: Crop rotation systems in potato farming from Canada and the USA demonstrate positive yield impacts.
[Statement 7]: Three out of five replicated, controlled studies found that crop rotation increased crop yield in some years or with certain rotation crops.
[Statement 8]: Two studies on crop rotation found both yield increases and decreases depending on the rotation crops used.
[Statement 9]: One study found that crop rotation increased profit.
[Statement 10]: Modifications to tillage practices show variable results on crop yields.
[Statement 11]: In the USA, nine replicated, controlled studies found that reduced tillage systems resulted in higher cereal yields compared to conventional tillage in some or all comparisons.
[Statement 12]: Three of the nine US studies on reduced tillage also found lower cereal yields in some comparisons.
[Statement 13]: Five replicated, randomized, controlled studies from the USA found higher fruit or vegetable yields with reduced tillage in some comparisons.
[Statement 14]: Two of the five US studies on reduced tillage for fruits and vegetables also found lower yields in some comparisons.
[Statement 15]: For no-tillage systems, eight replicated, controlled studies from the USA found higher crop yields compared to conventional tillage in some or all comparisons.
[Statement 16]: Seven studies on no-tillage systems in the USA found lower crop yields compared to conventional tillage in some or all comparisons.
[Statement 17]: Cover crop systems from the USA show predominantly negative to neutral effects on crop yields.
[Statement 18]: Six replicated, controlled studies found lower cash crop yields in plots with winter cover crops compared to plots without them in some comparisons.
[Statement 19]: Three studies found higher yields in plots with winter cover crops, while eight studies found inconsistent differences.
[Statement 20]: Studies found higher cash crop yields in plots that had legumes as winter cover crops compared to non-legumes.
[Statement 21]: Studies from the USA on organic fertilizer use compared to inorganic fertilizers show mixed results.
[Statement 22]: Three replicated, randomized, controlled studies found lower yields with organic fertilizer compared to inorganic fertilizer in some or all comparisons.
[Statement 23]: Four studies from other regions found higher yields with organic fertilizer in some comparisons.
[Statement 24]: Compost addition studies from the USA show variable effects on crop yields.
[Statement 25]: Three US studies found higher crop yields in plots with added compost in some or all comparisons.
[Statement 26]: Two US studies on compost addition found inconsistent differences in crop yields.
[Statement 27]: Three US studies found similar crop yields with or without added compost.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What is the evidence from North America on how different farming systems affect crop yields?
_claude-sonnet-4__For which natural pest control interventions is there evidence about the duration of their effects?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Specific information about the duration of effects for natural pest control interventions is limited.
[Statement 2]: For push-pull cropping systems, there is an indication of sustained economic benefits over time.
[Statement 3]: One study on push-pull cropping systems found higher production costs in the first year but equal or lower costs in the following five years.
[Statement 4]: One study on planting flowers for pest regulation found more species of natural enemies in flower strips over time.
[Statement 5]: The presence of more species of natural enemies in flower strips over time suggests temporal persistence of benefits.
[Statement 6]: For chemical attractants to natural enemies, effects varied between study dates in some cases.
[Statement 7]: The variation in the effects of chemical attractants indicates temporal variation in the effectiveness of the attractants.
[Statement 8]: For ant exclusion methods, effects varied between sampling dates.
[Statement 9]: One study on ant exclusion specified effects at times of peak pest abundance only.
[Statement 10]: Most of the evidence does not provide specific quantitative data about how long natural pest control interventions remain effective.

[Statement 1]: Several companion planting methods are available to enhance natural pest control.
[Statement 2]: Push-pull systems combine trap and repellent crops.
[Statement 3]: Studies of push-pull systems found increased parasitism of stem borer larvae, more natural predators, and fewer pests and witchweeds.
[Statement 4]: Studies of push-pull systems also found less pest damage and higher yields.
[Statement 5]: Intercropping involves planting more than one crop per field.
[Statement 6]: Studies showed increased ground beetle abundance when cabbage was intercropped with French beans or clover.
[Statement 7]: Alley cropping uses hedgerows of trees or shrubs between crop alleys.
[Statement 8]: One study of alley cropping found more wasps and spiders but fewer ladybirds.
[Statement 9]: The effects of alley cropping on pests varied between study sites and pest life stages.
[Statement 10]: Planting flowers for pest regulation has shown greater pest reduction in fields with planted flower strips.
[Statement 11]: Fields with planted flower strips have shown higher proportions of parasitized pests.
[Statement 12]: Growing non-crop plants that produce chemicals to attract natural enemies resulted in higher numbers of natural enemies.
[Statement 13]: Growing non-crop plants that produce chemicals to attract natural enemies resulted in decreased pest populations or damage.
[Statement 14]: Cover crops in arable fields can provide pest regulation benefits.
[Statement 15]: Some studies on cover crops found fewer aphids and reduced disease severity.
[Statement 16]: Natural regeneration of ground cover beneath perennial crops shows mixed effects on pest control.
[Statement 17]: Some studies found more natural enemies and fewer pests in fruit tree and vine systems with natural regeneration of ground cover.
[Statement 18]: Mixed pastures reduce weeds and some pest groups compared to monoculture systems.
[Statement 19]: Planting hedgerows around fields increases parasitism of pest eggs.
[Statement 20]: Planting hedgerows around fields provides more natural enemies.
[Statement 21]: One study found higher parasitism rates in tomato fields with hedgerows compared to fields with weedy edges.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What methods involving companion planting are available to enhance natural pest control?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: The evidence on soil amendments and management practices for weed control shows mixed results.
[Statement 2]: Incorporating plant remains into soil that produce weed-controlling chemicals, known as allelopathic plant remains, showed varied effectiveness.
[Statement 3]: Six studies on allelopathic plant remains found three studies with reduced weed growth and three with effects varying between years, weed groups, or weeding methods.
[Statement 4]: Four additional studies on allelopathic plant remains found two with reduced weed growth.
[Statement 5]: One study found that allelopathic residues applied too far in advance had reverse effects on weed growth.
[Statement 6]: Two studies on allelopathic plant remains found that effects varied between trials, weed species, or residue type.
[Statement 7]: Two studies found the weed-reducing effect from incorporating allelopathic plant remains did not last beyond a few days or weeks.
[Statement 8]: Soil tillage practices affect weed populations.
[Statement 9]: A comparison of no tillage to reduced tillage showed mixed results for weed populations.
[Statement 10]: In a comparison of tillage practices, four studies found fewer weeds with no tillage in some or all comparisons, but two of these also found more weeds in some comparisons.
[Statement 11]: One study found more weeds with no tillage compared to reduced tillage.
[Statement 12]: One study found similar weed amounts between no tillage and reduced tillage.
[Statement 13]: One study found fewer weed species with no tillage compared to reduced tillage.
[Statement 14]: Cover crops in arable fields demonstrated variable weed control effects.
[Statement 15]: Four studies found fewer weeds with cover crops in some or all comparisons compared to plots without cover crops.
[Statement 16]: One study found more weeds with winter cover crops in some comparisons compared to plots without cover crops.
[Statement 17]: Two studies found inconsistent effects of cover crops on weeds.
[Statement 18]: One study found similar weed amounts in plots with cover crops compared to plots without cover crops.
[Statement 19]: One study found fewer weed species with winter cover crops in one of three comparisons.
[Statement 20]: Mixed organic and inorganic soil amendments increased soil microbial biomass and activity.
[Statement 21]: Mixed organic and inorganic soil amendments reduced soil erosion.
[Statement 22]: Mixed organic and inorganic soil amendments increased soil organic carbon and nutrients.
[Statement 23]: The direct effects of mixed organic and inorganic soil amendments on weeds were not specifically documented.
[Statement 24]: Ground cover using mulch after restoration planting increased total plant cover in one study.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What does the evidence say about using soil amendments or soil management practices to control weeds?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Several alternative management strategies to routine, full-field cutting exist for pest control in pasture and grassland systems.
[Statement 2]: Using grazing instead of cutting shows mixed effects on natural enemies and pests, with some species and groups affected on some dates but not others.
[Statement 3]: One of five studies found more pests when grazing was used instead of cutting, while two studies found no effect on pests.
[Statement 4]: One of two studies on delayed mowing or first grazing found more pest insects in late-cut plots, while one found no effect.
[Statement 5]: The strategy of delayed mowing or first grazing showed mixed effects on natural enemies, with some predator groups affected differently.
[Statement 6]: Eight studies tested the strategy of leaving part of a pasture uncut.
[Statement 7]: Two studies found a decrease in pest numbers in partially cut plots, while two other studies found an increase in pest numbers.
[Statement 8]: The strategy of leaving areas uncut showed benefits for natural enemies.
[Statement 9]: Three studies found an increased abundance of predatory insects or spiders in partially cut areas.
[Statement 10]: Two studies found higher predator-to-pest ratios in partially cut areas.
[Statement 11]: Rotational mowing is a strategy that involves mowing strips in alternate years or leaving rotational areas uncut.
[Statement 12]: Studies on rotational mowing focused primarily on butterfly and moth conservation rather than on pest control specifically.
[Statement 13]: Five studies from North America found that compared to monocultures, mixed pastures showed one study with fewer pests, and two studies with reductions in some pest groups.
[Statement 14]: Compared to monocultures, one study of mixed pastures found no effect on pests, and one study found more pests.
[Statement 15]: Studies on reduced cutting frequency primarily examined effects on butterflies and moths rather than on pest control.
[Statement 16]: Studies on reduced cutting frequency showed mixed results for different species.
[Statement 17]: There is limited evidence available on the effects of a raised mowing height for pest control.
[Statement 18]: One study on raised mowing height focused on reptile behavior rather than on pest control effects.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__In pasture and grassland systems, what are some alternative management strategies to routine, full-field cutting for pest control?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Allowing natural or unmanaged vegetation to persist within perennial crops and pastures has multiple documented effects across different biological and agricultural systems.
[Statement 2]: Studies have found varying effects between different groups of natural enemies when comparing natural versus bare ground covers.
[Statement 3]: Some studies found no difference in the numbers of natural enemies in crop canopies when comparing areas with ground cover to areas with bare ground.
[Statement 4]: In pastures and crops that were left partially uncut, there was an increased abundance of predatory insects or spiders in the crop field or pasture area.
[Statement 5]: More predators were found in the unharvested or unmown areas of fields and pastures.
[Statement 6]: Allowing natural or unmanaged vegetation to persist provides consistently documented soil health benefits.
[Statement 7]: Soils with ground cover have increased microbial biomass compared to bare or tilled soils.
[Statement 8]: In perennial crop systems, soils with ground cover have more organic matter compared to soils without ground cover.
[Statement 9]: Multiple studies have documented increased nitrogen levels in soils with ground cover.
[Statement 10]: Ground cover provides erosion control benefits.
[Statement 11]: There is less soil erosion in areas with ground cover compared to bare or tilled soils.
[Statement 12]: Ground cover improves the water-stability of soil aggregates.
[Statement 13]: Olive groves with natural ground cover had higher reptile species richness and diversity than olive groves with bare ground.
[Statement 14]: Olive groves with natural ground cover had more reptiles overall compared to olive groves with bare ground.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What are the overall effects of allowing areas of natural or unmanaged vegetation to persist within perennial crops or pastures?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Beneficial interventions for reducing pest populations include several integrated pest management approaches.
[Statement 2]: Isolating colonies of beneficial ants increases predatory ant occupation in trees.
[Statement 3]: Increased predatory ant occupation in trees results in lower pest damage and higher yields.
[Statement 4]: Planting flower strips shows greater pest reduction and higher proportions of parasitized pests in fields.
[Statement 5]: Using pesticides only when pests reach threshold levels provides satisfactory pest control.
[Statement 6]: Using pesticides only when pests reach threshold levels requires fewer pesticide applications and lower production costs.
[Statement 7]: Push-pull cropping systems that combine trap and repellent crops increase parasitism of pest larvae.
[Statement 8]: Push-pull cropping systems reduce pest numbers and provide higher yields and economic benefits.
[Statement 9]: Excluding ants that protect pests increases parasitism by natural enemies and reduces pest numbers in some studies.
[Statement 10]: Incorporating parasitism rates when setting thresholds for insecticide use results in acceptable levels of crop damage.
[Statement 11]: Adding compost to soil reduces some crop diseases.
[Statement 12]: Planting hedgerows increases parasitism of pest eggs and reduces pest numbers.
[Statement 13]: Planting hedgerows increases natural enemy populations.
[Statement 14]: Using chemicals to attract natural enemies increases parasitism and reduces pest numbers in some studies.
[Statement 15]: Growing non-crop plants that produce chemicals to attract natural enemies increases natural enemy numbers.
[Statement 16]: Growing non-crop plants that produce chemicals to attract natural enemies decreases pest populations and damage while increasing crop yields.
[Statement 17]: Using mass-emergence devices can increase parasitism rates at some sites.
[Statement 18]: Leaving part of crops unharvested increases predation and parasitism rates of pest eggs.
[Statement 19]: Leaving part of crops unharvested provides mixed effects on pest numbers.
[Statement 20]: Mixed pasture systems reduce some pest groups compared to monocultures.
[Statement 21]: Altering the timing of insecticide use can reduce pests and disease damage when applied early rather than late in the growing season.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What are some of the most beneficial interventions for reducing pest populations?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Several potential negative economic impacts on yield and profit from implementing natural pest control strategies have been identified.
[Statement 2]: Threshold-based pesticide spraying had inadequate pest control in one study.
[Statement 3]: One study found that crop damage increased with threshold-based pesticide spraying compared to conventional preventative spraying regimes.
[Statement 4]: Implementing push-pull cropping systems resulted in higher production costs in the first year.
[Statement 5]: The costs of push-pull cropping systems became equal or lower in years following the first year of implementation.
[Statement 6]: Using planted flower strips had inconsistent effects on crop damage by pests.
[Statement 7]: One study found more damage by caterpillars in tomatoes next to planted flower strips compared to bare ground.
[Statement 8]: Another study found more pests on tomatoes next to planted flower strips compared to unplanted field margins.
[Statement 9]: Reducing pesticides had inconsistent or no effects on some invertebrates or birds in eight studies.
[Statement 10]: Reducing herbicide use had no or mixed effects on birds, invertebrates and plants in five studies.
[Statement 11]: Some studies found mixed effects on yield depending on site, year, and pest stage or type.
[Statement 12]: One study found that effects on profits varied between sites and years when using threshold-based spraying compared to conventional regimes.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What are the potential negative economic impacts on yield and profit from implementing natural pest control strategies?
_claude-sonnet-4__As an alternative to creating specific habitats like beetle banks, what other actions can provide refuge for natural enemies from farming operations?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Several alternatives to beetle banks can provide refuge for natural enemies from farming operations.
[Statement 2]: Planting nectar flower mixtures or wildflower strips has been shown to have positive effects on invertebrates.
[Statement 3]: Studies reported that planting wildflower strips resulted in increased abundance and species richness or diversity of invertebrates.
[Statement 4]: Flower strips have been shown to support ground beetle species that were rarely found in crops.
[Statement 5]: Planting grass buffer strips or margins around arable or pasture fields increases arthropod abundance, species richness, and diversity.
[Statement 6]: Planting nettle strips resulted in a higher number of aphid predator species in field margins.
[Statement 7]: Three insect families, including green lacewings, were only found on nettles in certain studies.
[Statement 8]: Providing or retaining set-aside areas in farmland showed benefits to wildlife groups.
[Statement 9]: Set-aside areas in farmland provide habitat for overwintering and refuge for wildlife.
[Statement 10]: Leaving overwinter stubbles provides benefits to plants, insects, spiders, mammals, and farmland birds.
[Statement 11]: Studies found that leaving overwinter stubbles resulted in higher densities of farmland birds in winter.
[Statement 12]: Leaving field margins unsprayed within the crop as conservation headlands creates refuge areas within fields.
[Statement 13]: Planting new hedges can provide habitat for natural enemies.
[Statement 14]: Studies from France and China found more natural enemies in hedges than in adjacent crops.
[Statement 15]: The effects of planting new hedges varied between crop types, hedge species, and years.
[Statement 16]: Reducing tillage had positive effects on earthworms and some invertebrates.
[Statement 17]: Reducing tillage led to increased biomass, species richness, or abundance of earthworms.
[Statement 18]: Reducing tillage resulted in a greater abundance of some invertebrates.
[Statement 19]: Taking field corners out of management provides undisturbed refuge areas for natural enemies.
[Statement 20]: Creating uncultivated margins around arable or pasture fields provides undisturbed refuge areas for natural enemies.

[Statement 1]: Several interventions show effectiveness for reducing pest populations in perennial crop systems such as orchards.
[Statement 2]: Beneficial ant management is an effective intervention for reducing pest populations.
[Statement 3]: Isolating colonies of beneficial ants leads to higher predatory ant occupation of cashew trees.
[Statement 4]: Isolating colonies of beneficial ants leads to lower pest damage.
[Statement 5]: Isolating colonies of beneficial ants leads to higher yields.
[Statement 6]: Excluding ants that protect pests showed mixed results across different crops.
[Statement 7]: The effects of excluding ants that protect pests varied between natural enemy species, sampling dates, sites, and crop varieties.
[Statement 8]: Ground cover management through allowing natural regeneration beneath perennial crops shows promise.
[Statement 9]: Some studies found fewer pests in regenerated ground covers compared to bare ground covers.
[Statement 10]: The effects of ground cover management varied for different pest or disease groups.
[Statement 11]: Threshold-based pesticide application is an important intervention.
[Statement 12]: Using pesticides only when pests reach threshold levels can satisfactorily control pests in some cases, though some studies reported inadequate pest control.
[Statement 13]: Applying pesticides only when pests reach threshold levels typically requires fewer pesticide applications.
[Statement 14]: Applying pesticides only when pests reach threshold levels results in lower production costs.
[Statement 15]: Incorporating parasitism rates when setting thresholds for insecticide use resulted in acceptable levels of crop damage from pests in tomato crops.
[Statement 16]: The finding regarding the incorporation of parasitism rates when setting insecticide thresholds was based on a single study.
[Statement 17]: The evidence for pest reduction interventions comes from various perennial crops including cashew, apple, grape, lemon, olive, pear, cherry, grapefruit, orange, pecan, and satsuma mandarin.
[Statement 18]: Study results for pest reduction interventions often showed mixed effects depending on specific conditions and pest types.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__In perennial crop systems such as orchards, which interventions are most effective for reducing pest populations?
_claude-sonnet-4__What actions involving structural changes within or around fields, like planting trees or grass strips, can be used to enhance natural pest control?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Several structural modifications within or around agricultural fields can enhance natural pest control.
[Statement 2]: Planting grass buffer strips or margins around arable or pasture fields increases arthropod abundance, species richness, and diversity.
[Statement 3]: Some studies found that planting grass buffer strips or margins had no clear effect on invertebrate pest populations.
[Statement 4]: Creating beetle banks provides habitat for predatory invertebrates.
[Statement 5]: Creating beetle banks can result in pest reduction, with the largest pest reductions found in areas closest to the beetle banks.
[Statement 6]: The effects of beetle banks on predator movement to adjacent crops can be variable.
[Statement 7]: Planting flower strips in fields demonstrates mixed results for pest control.
[Statement 8]: Some studies found that planting flower strips resulted in greater pest reduction and higher proportions of parasitized pests.
[Statement 9]: Some studies found increased pest numbers on crops adjacent to flower strips.
[Statement 10]: Planting nettle strips in field margins resulted in higher numbers of aphid predator species.
[Statement 11]: Certain insect families like green lacewings were found only on nettles when nettle strips were planted.
[Statement 12]: Hedgerow establishment and management provides natural pest control benefits.
[Statement 13]: Planting new hedges supports a higher abundance of beetles and spiders than crop fields.
[Statement 14]: Literature reviews have found lower pest outbreaks in areas with new hedges.
[Statement 15]: Planting hedgerows resulted in higher proportions of parasitized pest eggs in tomato fields compared to fields with weedy edges.
[Statement 16]: The effect of higher proportions of parasitized pest eggs from hedgerows was observed up to 100 meters into the crop.
[Statement 17]: Fields with hedgerows provided more natural enemies of pests.
[Statement 18]: Alley cropping, which involves intercropping with trees, increases the diversity of beneficial soil organisms like arbuscular mycorrhizal fungi.
[Statement 19]: Creating uncultivated margins around fields provides additional structural habitat modifications that support beneficial wildlife.
[Statement 20]: Taking field corners out of management provides additional structural habitat modifications that support beneficial wildlife.
[Statement 21]: The direct pest control effects of creating uncultivated margins and taking field corners out of management require further study.

[Statement 1]: Several alternative strategies to routine, preventative pesticide spraying exist for managing pests in agricultural production.
[Statement 2]: Threshold-based pesticide application involves using pesticides only when pests or crop damage reach specific threshold levels.
[Statement 3]: Threshold-based pesticide application has been shown to require fewer pesticide applications and lower production costs while maintaining similar crop damage and yields compared to conventional spraying regimes.
[Statement 4]: Crop rotation systems can reduce pest populations and crop diseases.
[Statement 5]: Studies found fewer insecticide treatments were needed on rotated plots in crop rotation systems.
[Statement 6]: Crop rotation systems have been found to increase crop yield in some years.
[Statement 7]: Push-pull cropping systems combine trap and repellent crops.
[Statement 8]: Push-pull cropping systems have been found to increase parasitism of stem borer larvae.
[Statement 9]: Push-pull cropping systems result in more natural predators and fewer pests.
[Statement 10]: Push-pull cropping systems result in less pest damage and higher yields.
[Statement 11]: Habitat management approaches include planting flower strips, which can provide greater pest reduction.
[Statement 12]: Planting flower strips can lead to higher proportions of parasitized pests in fields and farms.
[Statement 13]: Planting flower strips can increase the numbers of natural enemies.
[Statement 14]: Creating beetle banks has been shown to increase invertebrate predators.
[Statement 15]: Beetle banks can make economic savings if the beetle banks prevent pests from reaching spray thresholds.
[Statement 16]: Alley cropping systems have shown mixed results but can affect natural enemy populations and pest levels.
[Statement 17]: Using parasitism rates when setting thresholds for insecticide use has resulted in acceptable levels of crop damage from pests.
[Statement 18]: Organic farming systems have been studied as an alternative approach to conventional farming.
[Statement 19]: Organic farming systems have shown different effects on various species populations compared to conventional farming.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What are the alternative strategies to routine, preventative pesticide spraying for managing pests in agricultural production?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: The most effective actions for controlling pests in orchards and perennial tree crops involve multiple integrated approaches.
[Statement 2]: Planting or maintaining ground cover in orchards or vineyards can result in more natural enemies in plots with ground cover compared to plots without ground cover.
[Statement 3]: Allowing natural regeneration of ground cover beneath perennial crops can lead to more natural enemies.
[Statement 4]: Allowing natural regeneration of ground cover beneath perennial crops can lead to fewer pests or lower crop damage, though effects can vary for different pest groups.
[Statement 5]: Excluding ants that protect pests can result in fewer pests.
[Statement 6]: One study found greater tree growth when ants were excluded from trees.
[Statement 7]: Isolating colonies of beneficial ants resulted in predatory ants occupying more cashew trees.
[Statement 8]: The occupation of cashew trees by predatory ants led to lower pest damage and higher yields.
[Statement 9]: Using chemicals to attract natural enemies can result in more natural enemies.
[Statement 10]: Using chemicals to attract natural enemies can result in fewer pests.
[Statement 11]: Using chemicals to attract natural enemies can result in higher wheat yields.
[Statement 12]: Incorporating parasitism rates when setting thresholds for insecticide use resulted in acceptable levels of crop damage from pests in one controlled study.
[Statement 13]: Delaying herbicide use increased natural enemies in two randomized, replicated, controlled trials.
[Statement 14]: Delaying herbicide use was found to result in fewer pests in one of two experiments.
[Statement 15]: Alley cropping showed mixed results for pest control.
[Statement 16]: Some studies on alley cropping found increased natural enemies like wasps and spiders.
[Statement 17]: The effects of alley cropping on pests varied between sites and years.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What are the most effective actions for controlling pests in orchards or other perennial tree crops?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Alternative strategies to routine, preventative insecticide spraying for managing farm pests include several evidence-based approaches.
[Statement 2]: Crop rotation has been shown to reduce pest populations and crop diseases in potato farming systems.
[Statement 3]: Crop rotation can reduce the need for insecticide treatments in potato farming systems.
[Statement 4]: Push-pull systems that combine trap and repellent crops increase parasitism of stem borer larvae.
[Statement 5]: Push-pull systems that combine trap and repellent crops provide more natural predators.
[Statement 6]: Push-pull systems result in fewer pests with less crop damage and higher yields.
[Statement 7]: Incorporating parasitism rates when setting thresholds for insecticide use allows for acceptable levels of crop damage while reducing pesticide applications.
[Statement 8]: Planting flower strips increases pest reduction and results in higher proportions of parasitized pests in fields and farms.
[Statement 9]: Planting flower strips supports more natural enemies.
[Statement 10]: Creating beetle banks provides refugia for predatory invertebrates.
[Statement 11]: Predatory invertebrates from beetle banks can reduce pest numbers, particularly in areas closest to the banks.
[Statement 12]: Using chemicals to attract natural enemies can increase parasitism and predation rates.
[Statement 13]: The effects of using chemicals to attract natural enemies vary by chemical type and application conditions.
[Statement 14]: Allowing natural regeneration of ground cover beneath perennial crops can increase natural enemy populations on the ground.
[Statement 15]: Natural regeneration of ground cover can lead to fewer pests and reduced crop damage.
[Statement 16]: Leaving part of the crop or pasture unharvested provides habitat for predatory insects and spiders.
[Statement 17]: Leaving a portion of a crop or pasture unharvested increases predation and parasitism rates of pest eggs.
[Statement 18]: Excluding ants that protect pests can increase parasitism by natural enemies in fruit trees.
[Statement 19]: Excluding ants that protect pests can reduce pest numbers in fruit trees.
[Statement 20]: Isolating colonies of beneficial ants can increase predatory ant occupation and reduce pest damage.
[Statement 21]: Organic farming systems provide alternatives to synthetic pesticides.
[Statement 22]: The effects of organic farming systems on pest management vary by implementation.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What are some alternative strategies to routine, preventative insecticide spraying for managing farm pests?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Evidence from multiple studies demonstrates that various natural pest control interventions can increase parasitism of pests by natural enemies.
[Statement 2]: Excluding ants that protect pests resulted in greater parasitism of pests by natural enemies in one of two replicated, controlled studies from Japan and the USA.
[Statement 3]: One study on excluding ants that protect pests found greater parasitism at one site but no effect at another.
[Statement 4]: Push-pull cropping systems increased parasitism of stem borer larvae in two randomised, replicated, controlled studies from Kenya.
[Statement 5]: One study on push-pull cropping systems found no effect on egg parasitism.
[Statement 6]: Planted flower strips led to higher proportions of parasitized pests in three replicated studies from Italy and the USA.
[Statement 7]: Using chemicals to attract natural enemies increased parasitism in one review and two of five studies from Asia, Europe and North America.
[Statement 8]: Two studies on using chemicals to attract natural enemies found greater parasitism for some but not all chemicals, crops, sites or years.
[Statement 9]: One study on using chemicals to attract natural enemies found no effect.
[Statement 10]: Mass-emergence devices resulted in higher parasitism at one site in one randomised, replicated, controlled study in Switzerland.
[Statement 11]: The same study in Switzerland on mass-emergence devices found no effect at another site.
[Statement 12]: Leaving part of the crop unharvested or uncut increased predation and parasitism rates of pest eggs in unharvested strips in one replicated, controlled study from Australia.
[Statement 13]: Two of four studies on alley cropping from Kenya and the USA found that effects on parasitism varied between study sites, sampling dates, pest life stages or the width of crop alleys.
[Statement 14]: Two studies on alley cropping found no effect on parasitism.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What is the evidence that natural pest control interventions can increase the parasitism of pests by natural enemies?
